name: Baba Banda Singh Bahadur
birthPlace: Rajouri, Jammu (present-day Jammu and Kashmir, India)
excerpt: Baba Banda Singh Bahadur (born Lachman Dev, also known as Madho Das Bairagi) was a revered Sikh military commander and martyr who led the Khalsa Army against Mughal oppression. Appointed by Guru Gobind Singh in 1708, he established the first Sikh state, implemented land reforms, and struck fear into the Mughal Empire before his capture and brutal execution in 1716.
designation: Commander of the Khalsa Army; Founder of the First Sikh State

quickStats.label: Territories Conquered
quickStats.value: Punjab region including Sirhind and Samana

quickFacts.label: Original Name
quickFacts.value: Lachman Dev (from a Minhas Rajput family)

biographySections.label: Early Life
biographySections.value: Baba Banda Singh Bahadur was born on October 27, 1670 (or October 16 per some sources), in Rajouri, Jammu, to a poor Rajput family as Lachman Dev. His father, Ram Dev, was a farmer. From a young age, Lachman excelled in hunting, horsemanship, wrestling, archery, and swordsmanship. At age 15, a traumatic hunting incident‚Äîkilling a pregnant doe and witnessing her unborn fawns die‚Äîprofoundly affected him, leading him to renounce worldly life and become an ascetic. He adopted the name Madho Das Bairagi after meeting the sadhu Janaki Prasads and established a monastery at Nanded on the Godavari River. There, he practiced meditation and tantric arts, attracting followers. In 1708, Guru Gobind Singh visited his dera during a hunt with Mughal Emperor Bahadur Shah I. Impressed by the Guru's spiritual power, Madho Das submitted, declaring himself the Guru's "banda" (slave). Baptized with Khanda di Pahul, he was renamed Banda Singh Bahadur and tasked with leading the fight against Mughal tyranny in Punjab (Wikipedia; SikhiWiki).

biographySections.label: Contributions/Service
biographySections.value: Banda Singh's primary contribution was militarizing the Sikh resistance post-Guru Gobind Singh's passing in 1708. Commissioned with five arrows, a nagara (drum), and a hukumnamah (edict), he arrived in Punjab in 1709, rallying Sikhs and peasants oppressed by Mughal rule. He organized the Khalsa into a fighting force, issued coins, and established administrative centers. His campaigns sacked tyrannical strongholds like Samana (November 1709) and defeated Wazir Khan at the Battle of Sirhind (May 12, 1710), avenging the martyrdoms of Guru Gobind Singh's sons and mother. Banda expanded Sikh influence across Punjab, from the Sutlej to Yamuna rivers, mobilizing Hindus, Jats, Gujars, and Sikhs. His leadership fostered unity against Mughal persecution, setting the stage for future Sikh sovereignty (SikhiWiki; Wikipedia).

biographySections.label: Key Reforms
biographySections.value: Banda Singh revolutionized Punjab's socio-economic structure by abolishing the zamindari (feudal landlord) system, granting land ownership directly to tillers and peasants. This empowered the lower castes and rural masses, redistributing wealth from Mughal elites. He appointed Sikh governors (e.g., Baj Singh at Sirhind) and issued orders under his seal from Lohgarh (his capital, formerly Mukhlispur). Revenue collectors (tahsildars) and police (thanedars) were established, promoting justice and ending practices like forced cow slaughter. These reforms symbolized the advent of "Satyug" (age of truth) as per his hukumnamahs, fostering equality and self-rule (Khafi Khan's accounts via SikhiWiki; Ganda Singh's Life of Banda Singh Bahadur).

biographySections.label: Compositions/Writings
biographySections.value: N/A ‚Äì Banda Singh was primarily a warrior and administrator, not a prolific writer. However, he issued hukumnamahs (edicts) in Guru Gobind Singh's name, such as the one promoting Khalsa conduct: "Deg O Teg O Fateh o nusrat bedirang / Yaft Az Nanak Guru Gobind Singh" (Victory through charity and sword, obtained from Guru Nanak-Gobind Singh). These emphasized Sikh ethics, prohibiting intoxicants and promoting unity (SikhiWiki).

biographySections.label: Final Years
biographySections.value: After initial successes, Mughal Emperor Bahadur Shah (d. 1712) and successor Farrukhsiyar launched relentless campaigns. Banda evaded capture in Shivalik hills, marrying a hill chief's daughter and regrouping. By 1715, imperial forces under Abdus Samad Khan besieged him at Gurdas Nangal for eight months. Starved and low on supplies, internal disputes (e.g., with Baba Binod Singh) led to surrender on December 17, 1715. Paraded through Lahore and Delhi in chains, Banda and 740 Sikhs endured public humiliation. On June 9, 1716, after watching his four-year-old son Ajay Singh tortured and killed, Banda himself was blinded, dismembered with hot pincers, and beheaded‚Äîremaining stoic throughout (Eyewitness accounts in Ibratnama by Muhammad Qasim; SikhiWiki).

spiritualLegacy.description: Banda Singh embodied the Khalsa ideals of miri-piri (temporal-spiritual authority), transforming Guru Gobind Singh's vision into a socio-political revolution. His martyrdom exemplified Sikh resilience, inspiring generations to resist oppression.
keyContributions: Baptized thousands into the Khalsa, including low-caste Hindus, expanding Sikhism's egalitarian base.
Established Lohgarh as a symbol of Sikh sovereignty, minting coins with "Sikka zad bar hast-o-bast / Fateh gobind shah-i badshah" (Coin struck in the name of Guru Gobind Singh).
Avenged Sikh martyrdoms, like the Sahibzade's, reinforcing the Guru's call: "When tyranny overtakes men, it is the duty of the sensitive to fight" (Wikipedia; SikhiWiki).

modernRelevance.description: Banda Singh's life highlights themes of anti-colonial resistance, social justice, and peasant empowerment, resonating in contemporary struggles against inequality and authoritarianism.
contemporaryImpact: Institutions named after him, e.g., Baba Banda Singh Bahadur Engineering College (Fatehgarh Sahib) and Inter-State Bus Terminus (Mohali).
Symbol in Sikh historiography as the "first Sikh general," influencing narratives of self-determination in India and diaspora communities.
Annual commemorations at Chappar Chiri (battle site) and Gurdwara Banda Bahadur (Delhi) promote his legacy of reform and martyrdom.

quotes.context: From a hukumnamah issued during sieges, rallying Sikhs to uphold Khalsa principles amid Mughal persecution.

timeline.event: Born as Lachman Dev in Rajouri; early life marked by hunting prowess.
Became ascetic after hunting incident; named Madho Das Bairagi.
Met and baptized by Guru Gobind Singh at Nanded; renamed Banda Singh.
Sacked Samana; first major victory against Mughals.
Battle of Sirhind: Killed Wazir Khan; conquered province.
Raided Lahore suburbs; expanded Sikh influence in Majha.
Besieged and captured at Gurdas Nangal after 8-month siege.
Martyred in Delhi: Son killed first; endured torture before execution.

historicalContext.period: Early 18th century (Mughal Empire's decline under Aurangzeb's successors).
historicalContext.politicalSituation: Mughal tyranny peaked with persecutions against non-Muslims; Emperor Bahadur Shah I (r. 1707‚Äì1712) and Farrukhsiyar (r. 1713‚Äì1719) issued jihad against Sikhs. Punjab was a feudal province under governors like Wazir Khan of Sirhind.
historicalContext.socialConditions: Oppression of peasants, forced conversions, and caste hierarchies prevailed. Sikhs faced genocide post-1708 (Guru Gobind Singh's death); low-caste Hindus suffered under zamindars. Banda's reforms addressed agrarian exploitation.
historicalContext.significance: His uprising marked the shift from defensive Sikh resistance to offensive state-building, weakening Mughals and paving the way for the Sikh Misls and Ranjit Singh's empire by 1799 (cross-verified: Wikipedia, SikhiWiki, Ganda Singh's biography).
